Graphic abstract This review mainly focuses on the summary about iron (Fe, Ni, Co)-based transition metal compounds to anchor and catalyze LiPSs for lithium-sulfur batteries with some modification methods. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have a high theoretical capacity, which is considered as one of the most promising high-energy–density secondary batteries due to the double electrons reaction of sulfur. However, the shuttle effects of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and sluggish redox kinetics lead to their materials capacity loss and cycle stability deterioration, which restrains LSBs commercialization. Metallic compounds as additions can improve the electrochemical performance of the Li–S system, through the trap of LiPSs and accelerate the conversion of the soluble LiPSs. Among of them, the iron group elements (Fe, Ni, Co)-based compounds are the promising materials for the LSBs, due to their unique outer electronic structure and its tunable properties, low cost, abundant in the earth, environmental benignity, controllable and scalable prepared, and so on. In this review, we have made a summary for iron-based compounds to capture LiPSs according to lithium bond, sulfur bond and magnetic force. The type of iron-based compound including oxides, sulfides, nitrides, phosphides, carbides, and so on, and we have investigated the electrocatalytic mechanism of these materials. Besides, some improvement strategies are proposed, such as the engineering of the special micro/nanostructure, defect concentrations, band structures, and heterostructures. We hope to shed an in-depth light on the rationally design and fabrication of robust, commercial and stable materials for high-performance LSBs. Keywords Li-S batteries Iron-based compounds Shuttle effect Capture LiPSs Electrocatalysis Rational design 1 Introduction The effective utilization of renewable clean energy can considerably alleviate our dependence on fossil resources. To improve the efficiency of energy conversion and storage system, high energy and power densities must be indispensably desirable. Over the past two decades, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have made substantial contributions to the advancement of science and technology through their utilization as efficient energy storage devices [1,2]. However, the current capacities of LIBs are close to the theoretical limits. This, along with the growing energy demand of modern society, necessitates the development of novel electrochemical storage systems with even higher energy densities [3–6]. Li-S batteries with double electron involvement of S cathode and Li anode have a theoretical gravimetric energy density with 2600 Wh kg−1 [7]. In addition, elemental S is among the most promising cathodic materials with high commercial potentials due to its high abundance, low cost, environmental benignity, and nontoxicity [8–10]. The conversion of chemical to electrical energy in Li-S batteries is mainly based on the electrochemical reactions on S8 and Li2S1/2. However, energy conversion in these energy storage devices often suffer from the insulation of S8 and Li2S1/2, shuttle effect of the soluble intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) in the organic electrolyte, volumetric changes during cycling, and sluggish reaction kinetics [11–16]. Numerous studies have contributed to the research progress on Li-S batteries. For example, CMK-3, a highly ordered conductive mesoporous carbon framework, was used to restrain S agglomeration to increase the contact area and in turn, enhance the conductivity of the electrodes [17]. Carbon-based materials, such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene, have been widely studied to improve the performance of Li-S batteries [18–24]. Furthermore, previous reports showed that the introduction of heteroatoms could reduce the shuttle effect through chemical bonding [25–30]. In addition, similar to electrocatalysis, precious and transition metals have been used to catalyze the conversion of LiPSs [31–38]. Various modification method and mechanism have been explored over the last seven years [39]. It is very interesting that iron-based transition metal elements are very commonly used as central elements in lithium/lithium-ion secondary batteries [40–43]. For example, LiFePO4, LiCoO2, and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 were used as cathodes for LIBs, whereas Co3O4, Fe2O3, and NiO were employed as anodes [44–50]. The Li-S system involves electrocatalytic processes, as well as energy storage mechanisms in batteries. This makes transition metal-based compounds, such as oxides, nitrides, and carbides, widely used in this field [51–53]. Non-metallic ions affect the overall electron cloud density and state in the compound, leading to considerable changes in the conductivity, metal polarity, Li–S bond strength, and overall catalytic performance of compounds. Therefore, a summary on the properties of various metal compounds could help in design and fabrication of high-performance catalysts and electrodes. To date, iron-based compounds account for more than 8% of Li-S system. What’s more, attention has exploded in recent years indicating it possesses positive performance and great potential (Fig. 1 ). In this article, the intrinsic problems on Li-S systems were initially discussed. Then, various properties of these compounds were explored. The mechanisms and challenges of S conversion are presented in Section 2. Thereafter, the chemical forces between the metal compounds and LiPSs were explained in terms of the chemistries of the Li and S bonds. The catalytic mechanisms on different processes, such as liquid LiPSs to solid Li2S1/2 (Li2S2/Li2S, denoted as Li2S1/2), solid Li2S2 to solid Li2S, solid Li2S1/2 to liquid LiPSs conversion reactions, and some issues surrounding there were discussed in Section 3. In Section 4, the strategies to optimize the electrochemical performance of LSBs were classified into four categories, namely, micro/nanostructure engineering, defect engineering, band engineering, and heterostructure engineering. The main content of the article is shown in Fig. 2 . Finally, a perspective on Li-S batteries, along with some central challenges to be addressed in the future, was discussed. This review aims to provide the readers a thorough understanding of the optimization of the Li-S battery performance through the tuning of iron-based transition metal-based compounds, as well as the corresponding reaction mechanisms, which will be beneficial for the fabrication of highly efficient electrocatalysts. 2 Mechanism and challenges of S conversion in Li–S systems 2.1 Conversion mechanism of sulfur Li–S batteries with double electron involvement from the S cathode and Li metal anode have high theoretical gravimetric capacities. The overall redox reaction between S8 and Li+ can be written as (1) S 8 + 16 L i + + 16 e - ↔ 8 L i 2 S Despite the simplicity of Eq. (1), the total redox reaction can be divided into four stages (Fig. 3 a) [54,55]. As such, several reaction intermediates form in the cell. Fig. 3(b) shows the different types of S intermediates that are produced during the charging-discharging processes. During the discharge process (the blue curve) from 2.7 to 2.4 V, solid S8 is rapidly reduced to liquid Li2S8. Subsequently, from 2.4 to 2.1 V, the higher order Li2S8 species is reduced more slowly to lower ordered Li2S6 and Li2S4 species, which contributes approximately 25% of the theoretical capacity. The overpotential measured at approximately 2.1 V can be attributed to the generation of the solid Li2S1/2 species. At potentials below 2.1 V, the remaining theoretical capacity (75%) can be acquired from the complete reduction of Li2S4 to the solid Li2S1/2 species. Moreover, the reaction kinetics gradually decreased because of the increasing viscosity of the electrolyte from the dissolution of polysulfide during discharging. During the charging process (the red curve), a large overpotential was required to drive the reduction of solid Li2S1/2 to liquid polysulfide at approximately 2.3 V. Then, from 2.2 to 2.7 V, liquid polysulfide gradually oxidized to S8. However, the service life and theoretical capacity of the Li-S system do not meet the commercial requirements due to the poor conductivity of the S8 reactant and Li2S1/2 product, the shuttle effect of polysulfide, and sluggish kinetics of the overall redox reaction [56]. 2.2 Challenges in Li-S system To improve the specific capacity, cyclic stability, and rate performance of the Li-S system, the four primary factors that limit battery performance should be well understood. In this section, these factors, as well as the common methodologies employed to address them, are outlined. 2.2.1 Poor conductivity of S8 and Li2S1/2 The poor conductivities of reactant S8 and product Li2S are 5 × 10−30 and 3.6 × 10−7 S cm−1 at 298 K, respectively [57]. The highly insulating properties of these reactants limit the transfer of the electrons and hinder the electrochemical reactions, which makes a part of the reactants become a dead S layer [58]. As such, the theoretical capacity and maximum Coulomb efficiency are not attained. Furthermore, the low conductivity of the reactants results to a high internal resistance, which further increases the voltage polarization during the electrochemical reactions. This makes it difficult for the battery to operate under high current density and/or high S loading. 2.2.2 Volumetric change during cycling During battery operation, the positive electrode must withstand 80% of the structural change due to the difference in the densities of the S8 (2.07 g cm−3) and Li2S (1.66 g cm−3) reactants. In addition, the dissolution-deposition mechanism of elemental S causes a structural change after circulation, which leads to active material loss due to the sulfur falling off from the current collector. Therefore, a reasonable design of the positive electrode is critical to circumvent the issues imposed by the volumetric changes encountered during cycling. 2.2.3 Shuttle effect of polysulfide Under a concentration gradient, the soluble intermediates, Li2S n (3 ≤ n ≤ 8), diffuse from the cathode to the Li anode. Then, on the surface of the Li metal, the intermediate Li2S n can be reduced to solid Li2S1/2 (Fig. 3c). The reaction of the intermediates causes the polysulfide shuttle effect, which consequently results to severe S loss, low coulombic efficiency, and rapid capacity decay. 2.2.4 Sluggish redox reaction kinetic The kinetics of the overall redox reaction in the Li-S system are related to the cathodic conductivity, Li+ ion transport rate, and interfacial catalytic redox capacity. During the battery operation, the reaction rate gradually decreases because of the increasing viscosity of the electrolyte due to polysulfide dissolution. The calculated activation energy during the discharge process increases gradually (Fig. 3d) [59]. The sluggish reaction kinetics reduce the conversion rate of the reactants and severely limit the achievable capacity of the battery. Moreover, polysulfide could not be effectively transformed, which further intensifies the shuttle effect. 3 Iron family compound in Li-S battery Iron family elements such as Fe, Co, and Ni, exhibit high abundance, unique magnetic properties, environmental benignity, and superior biological compatibility, which make them promising materials for a wide array of applications. In the past five years, Fe-, Co-, and Ni-based compounds have been used widely in Li-S batteries due to their good catalytic properties, good polarizability, excellent stability, and ample electrochemical performance. The introduction of these compounds in the cathode can inhibit the shuttling of polysulfide and accelerate the overall redox reaction. In the following sections, the working mechanism of the Fe-, Co-, and Ni-based compounds on the Li-S battery systems are discussed. 3.1 Confining the sulfur to the cathodic side In earlier reports, S was physically confined to the cathode through the modification of the pore structure, specific surface area, and micro/nano framework of the carbon materials [17,60]. However, polar polysulfides tend to dissolve in the dimethyl ether/1,3-dioxolane (DME/DOL) electrolytes because of their poor interactions with non-polar carbon materials. Considering the chemical property of the Li–S bond, the introduction of heteroatomic or metallic compounds can restrain the shuttle effect through chemical forces [61–64]. 3.1.1 Lithium bond chemistry The chemistry of the Li bonds was first proposed in 1959 and generally accepted in 1970. Li bonds share the same chemistry with H bonds [65]. However, relative to H bonds, Li bonds do not exhibit saturation nor directional limitations because of the large atomic radii and metallic nature of the Li. Furthermore, Li bonds are more electrostatic due to their metallic nature. Lastly, its binding energy is much stronger than that of the H bond due to its larger dipole moment; however, it is still smaller than those of ionic interactions. In 2015, Goodenough et al. explained the interactions between LiPSs and electron-donating functional groups through the Li bond chemistry for the first time [66]. In 2017, Zhang et al. demonstrated the presence of Li bonds in the Li–S system for the first time through theoretical calculations and experimental observations [62]. In the Li bond chemistry, Li+ ions in the polysulfide act as proton donors and proton acceptors on the material through electrostatic interactions. Therefore, the Li bond chemistry can be explained broadly through the interaction between LiPSs and the S host [61]. Li+ ions interact well with highly electronegative non-metallic elements, such as O, N, and S [67]. Through theoretical calculations, Zhang et al. explained the dependence of the binding energies between graphene nanoribbons and Li2S4 on the type of the dopant used [26]. Without the dopants, the binding energy between Li2S4 and graphene was close to those of the DME/DOL solvent molecules (Fig. 4 b). After doping with O or N atoms, the binding energy became stronger than those of the DOL or DME solvents. As such, the deposition of the LiPSs on the surface of the heteroatoms was preferred over its dissolution in the organic electrolyte. In addition to non-metallic atoms, metal dopants can also alter the Li bond forces. Transition metal oxide compounds (TMOs) can capture dissolved LiPSs more effectively due to the strong polarity of their ionic bonds [37,68,69]. However, since most metal oxides exhibit poor electrical conductivities, they are often used in combination with carbon materials. For example, Cheng et al. introduced Fe3O4 and N-doped carbon into activated carbon cloth (ACC) and evaluated the adsorption performance of Fe3O4–NC@ACC towards Li2S4 (Fig. 5 ) [70]. The yellow Li2S4 solution with Fe3O4–NC@ACC became transparent after 0.5 h. The resulting absorbance was close to zero. In the XPS analysis, the peak corresponding to Fe became weaker and shifted towards lower binding energies after Li2S4 absorption, indicating the presence of chemical forces between polysulfide and Fe3O4. This result was further demonstrated by using a transparent system. Due to the strong adsorption effect, the Li anode was effectively protected. In another study, Zuo et al. measured the binding energy of O in the oxide and Li in the polysulfide after the adsorption test [71]. Peaks at 531.6 and 56 eV were observed in the O 1s and Li 1s XPS spectra, respectively. These can be attributed to the Li–O bond, thereby confirming that Li bonds were formed between the TMOs and LiPSs. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are known for their specific geometries, high surface areas, and rich pore structures. However, similar to TMOs, MOFs suffer from poor conductivities [72]. Lewis-acid metal centers with heteroatomic sites, such as N, S, and P, in MOFs are highly efficient LiPSs immobilizers [36,73–75]. In 2014, Xiao et al. designed Ni6(BTB)4(BP)3 (Ni-MOF) and Co6(BTB)4(BP)3 (Co-MOF) as cathodes for Li-S batteries, where BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate and BP = 4,4-bipyridyl [76]. Despite its higher electronic conductivity, the Co–MOF exhibited poorer cycling stability than Ni–MOF. This was attributed to the weaker coordination between Co and LiPSs. Wang constructed Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6] with a large open framework. Due to the internal transport of Li+/e− and the highly utilization of sulfur, electrode can deliver a high discharge specific capacity of 1291 mAh g−1 at 0.1C. What’s more, the excellent cyclic stability was attributed to the reduction of the shuttling effect because metal centers as the Lewis acid sites forms sulfur bonds with lithium polysulfide [73]. Yu et al. designed a tannic acid/FeIII complex-coated polypropylene (PP) (TA/FeIII-PP) separator, in which the Lewis acid-base sites of FeIII and dipole–dipole interactions between the phenol groups and polysulfides inhibited the shuttle effect [77]. As a result, the battery exhibited a highly stable capacity of 200 mAh g−1 at 2C after 1000 cycles of polarization. The poor electrical conductivities of oxides and MOFs hinder the electron transfer processes, which is not conducive for the conversion reactions. Furthermore, at high adsorption capacities, the transfer of LiPSs to the electrocatalytic reaction sites is difficult [78]. Therefore, other metal compounds with high conductivities, such as sulfides, nitrides, carbides, and selenides, have received considerable research attention. However, since the electronegativity of S (2.58) is almost similar to those of Se (2.55), N (3.04), P (2.19), and C (2.55), it is difficult to distinguish whether the chemical bonding was based on Li and/or S bonds [79]. 3.1.2 Sulfur bond chemistry Transition metals have good electrostatic interactions with the S (proton acceptor) atoms of LiPS because they are proton donors. After the introduction of metal compounds, Li and S bonds can improve the anchoring ability of LiPS [43]. For example, NiCo2O4 exhibits strong chemical interactions with LiPS. Specifically, the peaks corresponding to Co3+ and Ni3+ ions were weaker and shifted towards lower binding energies after absorbing the Li2S4 solution. This indicates that the charge of the S4 2− ions was transferred to higher-valence metal ions. Therefore, a S bond was formed between the NiCo2O4 and LiPSs (Fig. 6 a–d) [80]. The existence of S bonds can also be confirmed through theoretical calculations. From the binding configurations of Li2S2 and Co9S8 obtained through density functional theory (DFT) calculations, Nazar et al. showed that Li atoms preferred to bind with the three available neighboring S atoms in Co9S8, and the S atoms in Li2S2 tended to interact with the Co atom (Co9S8) of the (008) surface [81]. These results were further confirmed through XPS measurements, which also revealed the synergistic dual interactions based on S n 2−→Co δ+ and Li+→S δ− between the metal sulfide-based host material and polysulfides. In addition, selenides, nitrides, phosphates, and coordination compounds can also be found in the presence of S bonds. For example, NiCo2Se4 is a promising host material due to its metallic nature and the synergistic effect between the Ni and Co atoms in its structure [82]. Li preferentially binds to Se sites, and S reacts to Ni and Co ions. In addition, the binding energies towards LiPSs changed with the exposed crystal surfaces; from DFT calculations, the (110) surface showed a stronger anchoring ability to LiPSs than the (001) plane. Thin oxide layers inevitably form on the surface of metallic compounds, which can enhance their polysulfide anchoring effect to some extent. Wang et al. found that CoP nanoparticles strongly adsorbed polysulfides because their natural oxidation, which forms Co–O–P-like species, activated the surface Co sites, thereby allowing the binding of polysulfides on the surface through strong Co–S bonds (Fig. 7 a and b) [83]. With a surface oxide layer capable of confining polysulfides and an inner core suitable for conducting electrons, CoP nanoparticles are promising materials for stabilizing and improving the performance of S cathodes in Li-S batteries. The resulting S electrode with a high areal capacity of 5.6 mAh cm−2 exhibited good stability after 200 cycles of polarization even at a mass loading as high as 7 mg cm−2. Therefore, the novel method based on the surface-oxidation-induced polysulfide-binding can be potentially applied to a series of transition metal phosphides and chalcogenides to stabilize the performance of Li-S batteries. Surface oxidation occurs possibly due to the high electronegativity of oxygen (3.44). This should be considered in identifying the species that played a major role in anchoring and catalyzing the LiPSs. In monatomic systems, metal atoms form S bonds with the S atoms of LiPSs. In contrast, heteroatoms on carbon form Li bonds with the Li atoms of LiPSs. For example, Guo et al. designed a monatomic Co array mimic on ultrathin MOF nanosheets. The Co atoms were coordinated with O atoms, thereby forming Co-O4 moieties, which effectively captured polysulphides through Li and S bonds. The flux of the Li+ ions was homogenised through their strong adsorption on the surface of oxygen atoms, which in turn hindered the dendritic growth of Li [84]. Niu et al. constructed SANi (SA: single atom) on N-doped graphene (NG) to modify the separators [85]. From DFT calculations, the catalysts with SANi exhibited lower Gibbs free energy for the conversion of LiPSs and higher binding energies between Ni@NG and LiPSs. Therefore, the oxidised Ni sites of the Ni-N4 structure trapped LiPSs to form S x 2−⋯Ni–N bonding and accelerated the kinetic conversion of LiPSs (Fig. 7c and d). 3.1.3 Magnetic force Iron-based compounds exhibit unique magnetic properties that could be beneficial for the adsorption and trapping of the LiPSs [86,87]. Li et al. proposed a novel built-in magnetic-field-enhanced polysulphide trapping mechanism [88]. Ferromagnetic Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles (NPs) with a graphene shell on a flexible activated cotton textile fibre (ACT) were constructed as S hosts. To study the trapping mechanism of the Fe/Fe3C NPs, the colour change of the electrolyte in the custom-built liquid cell with pure ACT/S and ACT@Fe/Fe3C/S cathodes was digitally tracked (Fig. 8 a). After 3 h of constant current discharge, a dark brown region emerged around the surface of the ACT@Fe/Fe3C/S cathode, which demonstrated the trapping ability of the Fe/Fe3C NPs through magnetic force. In contrast to the chemical adsorption of metal oxides and sulphides, the magnetic field induced by the Fe/Fe3C NPs is critical in the trapping of the dissolved polysulphides in the proposed mechanism (Fig. 8b and c). Currently, only few reports are available on the effect of magnetic fields on Li-S systems. However, due to its immense potential, the application of magnetic fields in Li-S batteries should be explored and further developed in the future. 3.2 Catalytic reaction 3.2.1 Acceleration of liquid LiPS to solid Li2S1/2 The shuttle effect causes the rapid decay of capacity. Therefore, in order to weaken the shuttle effect, the interaction force between the host and polysulfide is increased. What’s more, the kinetics of polysulfide conversion into solid Li2S1/2 should be improved. Various metal-based compounds have been designed and developed to greatly improve the performance of Li-S system. (1) Oxide The kinetics of S conversion reactions on TMOs is limited by the intrinsically high charge transfer resistance on the oxides. To improve the charge transfer characteristics, highly conductive carbon materials are commonly added to TMOs. Yang et al. utilised α-Fe2O3 NPs embedded in porous graphene as S hosts [89]. Through cyclic voltammetry (CV), the conversion rate from soluble LiPSs to Li2S2 and then finally, to Li2S was found to increase with increasing Fe2O3 content in the host. Similarly, other studies have reported the successful adoption of Fe3O4 with higher conductivities [70,90,91]. For example, Chen et al. designed yolk-shell C@Fe3O4 nanoboxes as an efficient S host, which exhibited a capacity as high as 1104 mAh g−1 with an areal capacity of 6.07 mAh cm−2 at the first cycle. After 200 cycles, the capacity was well maintained at 850 mAh g−1 even at a S loading as high as 5.5 mg cm−2 [92]. On the other hand, Qin et al. designed Fe3O4-decorated porous graphene interlayer that can immobilize polysulphides effectively. At 1C, the capacity measured after 500 and 2000 cycles of polarization were 732 and 356 mAh g−1, respectively. These correspond to a capacity retention and decay rate of 49.0% and 0.02% per cycle, respectively [93]. Co oxides can also be used to enhance the reaction kinetics on Li-S batteries. Dou et al. demonstrated the possible transformations between Li2S n and Li2S2/Li2S on carbon cloth (CC) at different discharge–charge potentials through ex-situ Raman spectroscopy [94]. During the discharging process, the intensity of the signal corresponding to Co3O4 gradually decreased and that of the signal attributed to Li2S2/Li2S increased. During the charging process, the reverse was observed (Fig. 9 ). This proved the reversibility of the deposition and decomposition of the Li2S1/2 species on the Co3O4 surface. In general, the high polarity interface of the TMOs, particularly of Fe, Ni, and Co-based oxides, exhibit excellent anchoring abilities. However, their low conductivities result to poor catalytic performances, which severely limit the conversion between long-chain and short-chain LiPSs and the deposition-decomposition of Li2S2/Li2S. Therefore, studies on TMO-based cathodes should focus on improving their electron transfer efficiencies. Furthermore, strategies such as coupling the oxides with conductive matrices should be optimised. (2) Sulfide Compared with TMOs, transition metal sulphides (TMSs) exhibit higher conductivity and greater catalytic performance due to their metallic or half-metallic characteristic [95–99]. In addition, the sulfiphilic property gives it a strong interaction with polysulfide, which accelerates the electron transport between TMSs and LiPSs [100,101]. Zhang et al. synthesised CoS2/graphene compounds, which were assembled as symmetrical Li2S6-Li2S6 and asymmetrical Li-CoS2/graphene cells. At different CoS2 contents, the current density of the Li2S6-Li2S6 cells and peak voltage of the Li-CoS2/graphene cells obtained through CV indicated that CoS2 directly improved the conversion effect [31]. The novel method can be used to test the catalytic properties of metal-based compounds. Chen et al. designed an electrode with a layer-by-layer structure based on CoS2 NP-embedded porous carbon grew that on the sides of reduced graphene oxide (rGO). The average particle of the CoS2 NPs was 10 nm. The electrode exhibited a long cycle life (1000 cycles) at 5C with a capacity decay rate of 0.033% per cycle. At 1 and 5C, the calculated capacities were 1180.7 and 700 mAh g−1, respectively [102]. On the other hand, Fe- and Ni-based sulphides also exhibit good catalytic performance [103–106]. Chen et al. constructed Ni3S2 anchored into N/S co-doped rGO as a S host. The resulting Ni-based sulphide electrode exhibited good catalytic performance at a capacity of 6.72 mAh cm−2 at 0.05C and S loading of 5.8 mg cm−2 due to its large specific surface area, rich pore volume, three-dimensional conductive network, and excellent physicochemical properties [107]. Similarly, Manthiram designed porous nanoflower-like NiS2 grown on rGO. The rGO framework provided conduction paths for the fast charge transfer on the NiS2 -LiPS interface, which improved the kinetics of the LiPS redox conversion. This hybrid cathode with 75 wt% S registered a high capacity (16 mAh cm−2) even at a S loading as high as 21 mg cm−2 [3]. (3) Selenide The conductivity (1 × 10−3 S m−1) of Se is much higher than that of S (5 × 10−28 S m−1) [82,108]. Similar with TMSs, transition metal selenides (TMSes) present high defect densities and polar character. Although their preparation often involves complex and difficult procedures, the high conductivity and excellent catalytic activity of transition metal selenides (TMSes) make them suitable for electrocatalysis [109,110]. Zhang et al. designed a unique triple-phase interface between the catalyst, conductive support, and electrolyte to achieve synergism of the strong chemisorption, high electrical conductivity, and high electrocatalytic activity of electrode materials. The attained synergistic effect can regulate the kinetic behaviours of soluble LiPS and enable the uniform nucleation and controllable growth of solid Li2S in Li-S batteries [111]. In detail, trogtalite CoSe2 nanodots provided abundant exposed sites for the adsorption of liquid LiPS and regulated the nucleation density. At the same time, the intrinsic metallic nature of CoSe2 facilitated the rapid electron transfer. More importantly, the uniformly dispersed CoSe2 nanodots with an average size of 5 nm provided dense and uniformly distributed sulfiphilic active sites, which effectively shifted the equilibrium towards the nucleation and growth of Li2S. Therefore, through the well-designed triple-phase interface, the uniform nanoscale precipitation of Li2S was achieved, and the aggregation of particles was inhibited (Fig. 10 a and b). Considering cooperative triple-phase interfaces, a high initial capacity (916 mAh g−1) and good stability (459 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles) in a working Li-S battery was demonstrated at an unprecedented high rate of 6C (approximately 10 mA cm−2). Furthermore, DFT calculations demonstrated the catalytic effect of CoSe2 from the values of activation energy. Observations of structure and component changes during the cycle are necessary to better understand the nature of battery operation. Zhu et al. designed a N-doped carbon network@Co3Se4 cathode. The morphological and structural changes during the charge-discharge processes were ex-situ studied (Fig. 10d and e). The reversible changes in the surface thickness of carbon indicated that the Li2S deposition and decomposition processes on the substrate were sustainable. In addition, after the full charge state, the diffraction peaks corresponding to S8 and Co3Se4 became less defined and weakened, indicating that amorphous S may have been deposited on the surface of Co3Se4. At 0.2C, the initial capacity of this cathode was 1150.3 mAh g−1. After 800 cycles of polarisation at the same rate carried out for more than 5 months, the retained capacity was 531.0 mAh g−1 with an ultralow capacity reduction rate of 0.067% per cycle. The Coulombic efficiency was well maintained at 99.3% [112]. (4) Carbide Transition metal carbides (TMCs) exhibit high metallic conductivity and form chemical bonds with LiPSs in rapid surface reactions, which make them suitable as hosts for Li-S batteries [113–116]. Hou et al. prepared cathode materials based on ultrathin two-dimensional Fe3C nanosheets on mesoporous carbon (MC) [117]. DFT calculations revealed that Fe3C is a polar conductive compound with strong adsorption and excellent LiPS activation abilities, which can promote the capture and transformation of the LiPSs. As a S host in Li-S batteries, the 3D hierarchical conductive Fe3C-MC composite facilitated the electronic/ionic transfer, captured LiPSs to reduce the polysulphide shuttle effect, and enhanced the reaction kinetics simultaneously. Even at a high S loading of 9 mg cm−2, the Fe3C-MC composite exhibited a high initial specific capacity (1530 mAh g−1) at 0.1C. Furthermore, it registered highly stable capacities (approximately 700 mAh g−1) even after 100 cycles of polarisation at 0.5C. Yu et al. constructed Fe3C/C nanoboxes embedded on carbon nanofibres through electrospinning (Fig. 11 a–c) [118]. From first-principle DFT calculations (Fig. 11d), the Gibbs free energies of the conversion reaction from liquid LiPSs to Li2S2 decreased substantially, indicating that catalysis occurred on the surface of Fe3C. At 0.2C, this cathode exerted a high capacity (approximately 600 mAh g−1) after 100 cycles with a S loading of 5 mg cm−2. Currently, carbide research mainly focuses on Fe3C. Only a few reports on the application of Co- and Ni-based carbides in Li-S batteries are available [119–122]. (5) Nitrides Metal nitrides are promising chemical adsorption hosts and catalysts for Li-S batteries. They can improve the cycling performance through the suppression of the polysulphide effect by chemical bonding and increase the rate performance through the acceleration of the conversion reactions by decreasing the electrode polarisations [123,124]. Previous reports showed that N-based compounds form new crystal phases during cycling. For example, Qian et al. revealed that Co4N exhibited an electrochemical behaviour similar to that of CoS2, which explained the strong adsorption of Li2S6 on the Co4N surface [125]. In this system, Li–S bonds were broken, resulting to the partial sulfurization of the Co4N surface. On the other hand, Huang et al. demonstrated that Co4N was a pre-catalyst that transforms into highly active electrocatalysts, such as CoS x [126]. After five polarisation cycles, new phases, such as amorphous CoS x and CoS2 particles, were formed. Fig. 12(a) shows the schematic of the proposed electrochemical phase evolution. After 5 polarisation cycles, the liquid-liquid polysulphide interconversion, liquid-solid Li2S deposition, and solid-Li2S oxidation processes on the Co4N surface were faster. Considering these results, for some Co-based compounds, such as CoP, CoB, and CoSe2, the generated CoS x during cycling might be the true active phase (Fig. 12b). Therefore, the phase transitions of metal-based catalysts should be considered. To improve the poor catalytic activity of Ni3N, Huang et al. introduced Fe into hexagonal Ni3N. After the introduction of the metallic dopant, cubic Ni3FeN was formed [127]. During the cycling process, the more electropositive Fe ions in the corner sites were etched by LiPSs, which formed vacancies in the crystal lattice (Fig. 12c). This specific process enhanced the interface reaction kinetics of the LiPS. At 3C, the capacitance was greater than 800 mAh g−1 with a S loading of 4.8 mg cm−2 (Fig. 12d). Therefore, the in-situ phase evolution and vacancy formation processes were significant in regulating the catalytic reactions on the electrodes. (6) Phosphides Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) exhibit metallic characteristics and superconductivity, which are beneficial for the catalysis to improve electrochemical reactions. Compared with synthesis of nitrides and carbides, the phosphide reaction is relatively facile and simpler, which only requires the high temperature treatment of the P source. In other electrocatalytic systems, TMPs, such as Ni2P, CoP, and Fe2P, have attracted extensive research interest [44,128,129]. Therefore, the applicability of TMPs in Li-S batteries can be evaluated considering previously reported results. To improve the utilisation of active materials, TMPs can trap soluble polysulphides and effectively catalyse the deposition of Li2S [130–133]. Compared with cathodes based on other materials, Ni2P, Co2P, and Fe2P electrodes exhibit higher reversible capacities and improved cycling performances [134]. There is no apparent difference between the dissociation energies of these TMPs. However, among these materials, Fe2P has the best ability to trap Li2S and Ni2P exhibits the best electrochemical properties with capacity and capacity retention as high as 1024 mAh g−1 and 96% after 300 cycles of polarisation at 0.2C, respectively. In general, phosphides exhibit higher conductivities than oxides. Zhu et al. demonstrated that FeP exhibited better electrochemical performance than Fe oxides. FeP could shift the p band, which increased the electronic concentration in the Fermi level of the soluble LiPSs and enhanced the electron transfer rate [135]. (7) Coordination compounds Coordination compounds were also introduced into S-based cathodes due to their highly tuneable channel structure, sulfiphilic framework, and abundant metal catalytic sites. Zhang et al. designed a 3D nanocomposite S host based on defective Prussian blue nanocrystals and nanotubes [136]. The composite cathode exhibited fast kinetics for ion diffusion, low activation energy for the conversion of Li2S4 to Li2S2/Li2S, and strong adsorption of LiPS due to the Lewis acidic sites and [Fe(CN)6] vacancies in its 3D architecture. At 0.2C, the initial specific capacity of this electrode was more than 1400 mAh g−1. After 200 cycles of polarisation, the retained capacity was approximately 1100 mAh g−1. On the other hand, Shan et al. explored the use of metal phthalocyanine (MPc) compounds such as CuPc, CoPc, and FePc for the stabilisation of LiPSs [137]. Among these compounds, CoPc exhibited superior cycling stability with an approximate retained capacitance of 700 mAh g−1 after 250 cycles at 0.5C. Fig. 13 (a) shows the schematic of the conversion of LiPS during the discharge process. Initially, CoPc was anchored to LiPSs through Li–N bonds and the corresponding interactions between the S 2p orbitals and Co ions. As such, a (CoPc-Li2S x )− transition state was possibly formed. Then, Co–S bonds were formed, and S–S linkages were cleaved. Finally, either Li2S2 or Li2S was formed and then separated from CoPc by attaching to carbon. Yang proposed an integrated strategy to synthesise a high-performance cathode using a mediator. The resulting cathode composed of FePc, octafluoronaphthalene (OFN) and graphene (G/FePc + OFN) had an initial capacity of 1600 mAh g−1 at 0.2C [138]. FePc accelerated the kinetics of the conversion reaction of Li2S8 to Li2S4. On the other hand, OFN increased the rate of the conversion of Li2S4 to Li2S by facilitating the immobilisation and transfer of Li (Fig. 13b). The S content and electronic conductivity of metallic complexes are relatively low. In addition, the sluggish kinetics achieved using metallic complex-based electrodes yield poor rate performance and low cycling properties. Therefore, the usage of metallic complexes as electrode materials poses greater challenges than the utilisation of other metal compounds. (8) Metallic catalysts To achieve high specific surface energy, metallic subnano-/nano-catalysts are often dispersed or loaded into N-doped carbon through a weak force between the metal and N, which can anchor polysulphide and catalyse the conversion of LiPS [139–142]. Monodisperse nanosized metallic elements can be easily synthesised through heat treatment. Dong et al. produced Co NPs (nanoparticles) with an approximate average particle of 22 nm within a N-doped graphitic carbon matrix from a zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-67) precursor. At 0.005C, the cathode registered a capacity close to the theoretical capacity of S. After 500 cycles of polarisation at 1C, the retained capacity was 625 mAh g−1 [143]. Liu et al. embedded Co NPs with particle sizes ranging from 8–26 in N-doped CNT/nanopolyhedra (Co-NCNT/NP) using a CoZn-ZIFs precursor. During the heat treatment, the Co NPs catalysed the growth of the NCNTs on the surface of framework. After 200 cycles of testing at 0.5 C, the discharge capacity of the Co–NCNT/NP cathode was 657 mAh g−1 at an approximate areal S loading of 3.2 mg cm−2 [144]. Catalytic active sites are mainly found on the metal-sulphide interface. As such, exposing abundant metal sites is critical for the preparation of efficient and high-performance catalysts. Single atom catalysts (SACs) are typically dispersed on substrates or constrained in frameworks to maximise the utilisation of the metal [145]. In addition, the quantum size effect, tuneable electronic structures, and high surface free energy attained at the nanoscale pave a way for the further improvement of the catalytic performance of metals [146,147]. In 2018, Yang et al. reported the use of a SAC to for the catalysis of the conversion of LiPSs to Li2S2/Li2S for the first time [148]. Relative to a bare pore N-doped carbon electrode, a cathode with single-atom Fe (SAFe) reduced the phase nucleation overpotential required for the adsorption and conversion of LiPS. The structure of the deposited Li2S also affect the subsequent cycles. Qian et al. induced spherical epitaxial deposition of the solid sulphides. The resulting cathode registered a high capacity close to the theoretical value for single-atom Co (SACo) catalyst loaded in carbon paper (CP). SACo changed the electronic structure of the solid intermediates through d-p orbital hybridisation while sustaining the spherical epitaxial growth of Li2S (Fig. 14 a–c) [149]. This facilitated the continuous reversible conversion–decomposition of LiPS to Li2S. Table S1 summarizes the electrochemical properties of various metal-based compound. Although electrochemical properties have been greatly enhanced, the cycling performance remains a significant challenge, especially at high current densities. 3.2.2 Acceleration of solid Li2S2 to solid Li2S The theoretical capacity of the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S is 836 mAh g−1, which accounts for half of the total capacity of the Li-S battery. Accelerating the solid-solid conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S further develops the specific capacity of sulphur. However, this process is not studied extensively in previous reports because it occurs simultaneously with the transformation of Li2S4 into Li2S1/2 and is often difficult to characterise [150]. In this case, theoretical calculations can be employed to predict the catalytic properties [151]. Through DFT calculations, Zhang et al. demonstrated that there is not much difference between the free energies of S8 and Li2S4. On the other hand, the Gibbs free energies of the Li2S2 conversion to Li2S on Co/graphene and Fe/graphene surfaces were larger than that of the conversion on a Fe1Co3/graphene surface, indicating that the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S occurred more easily on the Fe1Co3/graphene electrode (Fig. 15 a) [152]. Additionally, the diffusion rate of Li+ ions during the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S should be improved. As shown in Fig. 15(b), the Li+ diffusion barrier of the Fe1Co3/graphene surface was lower, which imply the prompt kinetics of the conversion reaction of Li2S2 to Li2S on the Fe1Co3/graphene cathode. Through experimental investigations, Sun et al. determined the phenomenon caused by the catalytic conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S [153]. Amorphous CoS3 was introduced to S/CP@NCNT to reduce the dissociation energy of Li2S2. Based on the charging curve (Fig. 16 a and b), the onset potential required for S/CP@NCNT@CoS3 (1.99 V) was lower than that needed for the S/CP@NCNT composites. The capacity contribution of S/CP@NCNT@CoS3 was 75 mAh g−1. In addition, the slopes of the discharge curves of S/CP@NCNT@CoS3 and S/CP@NCNT and were different. The smooth slope below 2 V and long active time during the discharging of S/CP@NCNT@CoS3 confirmed that CoS3 catalysed the conversion of solid Li2S2 to solid Li2S. The peaks corresponding to ST 1− and S2− observed at the XPS spectra of the sample obtained after the discharge process can be attributed to Li2S2 and Li2S, respectively (Fig. 16e and f). The Li2S-to-Li2S2 peak ratio increased from 0.61 to 5.60 after CoS3 was incorporated into S/CP@NCNT. In situ synchrotron-based X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) was also performed during the discharge–charge processes (Fig. 16c and d). The pre-edge at 2470.1 eV can be attributed to Li2S2, whereas those observed at 2473.0 and 2475.3 eV can be assigned to Li2S. In the full discharge state, the pre-edge of the CoS3 catalyst that was attributed to Li2S2 was weaker, and those assigned for Li2S were more intense. Therefore, CoS3 accelerated the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S. 3.2.3 Acceleration of solid Li2S1/2 to liquid LiPSs The reversible oxidation of solid Li2S2 to LiPSs is important to ensure the stable circulation of components during the operation of Li-S batteries. However, the energy required to break the Li–S bond is very high due to the poor conductivity and slow oxidation kinetics of Li2S. Zhang et al. incorporated single atom Fe (SAFe) into porous N-rich carbon to decrease the energy needed to sever the Li–S bond in a Li2S/Li battery (Fig. 17 a) [154]. At 12C, the Li2S/Li battery recorded a specific capacity of 588 mAh g−1. On the other hand, the capacity decay rate at 5C was 0.06% per cycle. During the charging process, the Li2S in the [N–Fe···S–Li2] intermediate coordinated with SAFe. Then, the intermediate lost Li+ ions and electrons, which formed [N–Fe···S–Li]. Sequentially, the [N–Fe···S–Li] species combined with Li2S to form [N–Fe···S–Li−Li–S–Li2] during the deep charge. Finally, Li2S transformed into S8 (Fig. 17b). Liu et al. synthesised SAFe in a carbonaceous cage (SAFe-CN) as the cathode host through a sacrificial templated method using ZIF-8. LiPSs were restricted to the cathode, where it rapidly transformed to S8, due to the efficient mass migration in the system as well as the porous structure, abundant polar sites, and uniform dispersion of SAFe. At 4C, the resulting Li-S battery delivered a specific capacity of 605 mAh g−1. During 500 cycles of polarisation, the capacity decay rate was 0.06% per cycle while the S loading was 1.4 mg cm−2. At the same time, the cathode containing SAFe exhibited a lower overpotential, suggesting that the energy barrier of the Li2S decomposition on the SAFe-CN host was lower than that of reaction on the CN cathode. The experimental results corresponded well to the results of DFT calculations [155]. SACo is another promising single-atom material that can catalyse the decomposition of Li2S in Li-S systems [156–158]. Wan et al. designed cathodes based on SACo loaded on a N-doped graphene framework. XPS results revealed that the Co atoms were bound to pyridinic N. On the other hand, from the XANES and EXAFS measurements, the Co atoms in the Co-N/G composite were positively charged. Therefore, the Co atoms embedded into the N-doped graphene lattice coordinated with the N atoms to form Co-N-C coordination centres. The formation of Li2S at the initial stage of the discharge process indicated that SACo improved the kinetics of the electrochemical phase transition from the soluble LiPSs to the insoluble Li2S2/Li2S. Based on the results of the DFT calculations, the energy barriers for the formation and decomposition of Li2S were lower on the Co-N/G composite, implying that the reduction of S and oxidation of Li2S occurred easier (Fig. 17c) [159]. Furthermore, the changes of the S K-edge XANS revealed that Li2S underwent a reversible redox reaction during the electrochemical procedure (Fig. 17d and e). Zhang et al. also demonstrated that SACo can improve the kinetics of Li+ ion diffusion and accelerate the decomposition of Li2S in Li2S/Li batteries even in Li2S cathodes with high mass loading. The prepared electrode exhibited an outstanding rate performance and long cycle life. At 0.5C, the cathodes with an areal loading of 5.2 and 6.1 mg cm−2 delivered initial capacities as high as 674 and 584 mAh g−1, respectively [160]. Indeed, the bidirectional transformation of lithium polysulfide promoted by iron group elements (Fe, Ni, Co)-based compounds have been regarded as promising path in recent years [161–163]. Therefore, more attention should be paid to the design of bidirectional catalysts for high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries. 4 Modification methods In this chapter, the common methods, such as special micro/nanostructure engineering, defect engineering, band engineering, and phase engineering, employed to modify the transition metal-based materials and in turn, further improve the properties of Li-S batteries are discussed. 4.1 Micro/nano-structure engineering To improve the conductivity of S and counter the volume changes encountered during the cycling process, S is often dispersed on substances with a high specific surface area. As cathodic materials, metal compounds with special micro/nanostructures can increase the utilisation of S and prevent the formation of dead sulphur layers. For these applications, cathodes with porous, yolk-shell or hollow structures are widely used [164]. Porous structures provide enough space for the storage of sulphides to avoid agglomeration of particles and lessen volumetric changes during battery operation. Micro/nanopores can limit the shuttle effect of polysulphide while large pores can increase the S loading [165]. For example, Li et al. reported the synthesis of uniform Co-Fe mixed metal phosphide (Co-Fe-P) nanocubes with a highly interconnected pore architecture [166]. The Co-Fe-P nanocubes exhibited an abundant mesoporous structure with an average pore size of 47 nm. Its specific surface area was 93.5 m2 g−1. The synthesised mixed metal phosphide with a highly interconnected pore architecture, high intrinsic metallic conductivity and polar characteristics provided much electrical contact to the insulating S layer to maximise the utilisation of S and enhance the redox reaction kinetics. It also endowed abundant adsorption sites for the trapping of LiPSs and catalysed the conversion reaction to suppress the polysulphide shuttle effect. At 1C, the measured specific and areal capacities at a S loading of 5.5 mg cm−2 were 1200 mAh g−1 and 4.6 mAh cm−2, respectively. Although chemical bonds can reduce the polysulphide shuttle effect to some extent, their effects on S atoms far from the substrate are greatly weakened, particularly for electrodes with high S loading (Fig. 18 a). To circumvent this, 3D hollow structures are constructed, which are used as single nanoreactors that physically confine LiPS and effectively reduce the volume changes encountered during the S conversion process (Fig. 18b) [167–170]. These hierarchical morphologies include simple hollow, yolk-shell, multi-shell, and core-shell structures. For instance, Xu et al. constructed double-shelled Ni-Fe-P/N-doped carbon boxes as S host materials with strong chemical adsorption properties, good catalytic activity, and unique hollow structure to buffer the volume changes of sulphide [171]. Zhang et al. designed Ni2P yolk–shell sphere-encapsulated S, which contained abundant reaction and adsorption sites. At 0.2C, the cathode exhibited an approximate initial specific capacity of 1400 mAh g−1. After 100 cycles of polarisation, the retained capacity was more than 800 mAh g−1. Qiao et al. synthesised uniformly distributed nanosized NiS on 3D carbon hollow spheres through a hard-templated method [172]. In this unique structure, NiS exhibited strong chemical bonding interactions with the polysulphides, whereas the hollow carbon framework provided physical confinement and electron transfer pathways. Due to its multifunctional design, the electrode with a S loading of 2.3 mg cm−2 delivered a specific capacity of 695 mAh g−1 at 0.5C. Kim designed brain/coral-like hollow CoS2@N doped graphitic carbon as a S host [173]. The mesoporous and hollow structures endowed the composite cathode with high S loading (75 wt%) and abundant active sites, and reduced the volume expansion during lithiation. At 0.1C, the retained specific capacity of this cathode after 100 cycles of polarisation was approximately 900 mAh g−1. 4.2 Defect engineering Vacancies or defects as electronic carriers enhance the electrical conductivity and provide more active sites for adsorption and storage [175]. In addition, the vacancies may generate a local electric field at an atomic level, which can accelerate the diffusion of Li+ ions, trap polysulphides, and catalyse the conversion reactions [176–179]. The presence of O vacancies can improve the intrinsic electrical conductivity of materials. A localized electric field around the oxygen vacancy sites may form, which can facilitate the migration of Li+ ions in the crystal lattice. Wang fabricated dandelion-like CoO/C hollow microspheres with oxygen vacancies produced through Mn/Ni co-doping. When the Co2+ ions in the CoO crystal lattice were partially replaced by Mn2+ and Ni2+ ions with much larger ionic radii, the interspace between O2− ions in lattice may be squeezed. As such, O2− ions may shift to other crystal lattices, thereby forming the oxygen vacancies. As shown in Fig. 19 (a), an electric field was formed from the electrically neutral to the negatively charged region, in which the rate of Li+ ion diffusion increased during the discharge process. When the discharge step was complete, the negatively charged region became electrically neutral. At this moment, the electric field, which was in the opposite direction, facilitated the separation of Li+ ions from the electrode surface during the charging process. After 1000 cycles of polarisation at 2C, the cathode exhibited a satisfactory discharge capacity of 447 mAh g−1 at a S mass loading of 2.7 mg cm−2 [180]. Other anionic defects can also be introduced to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Zheng et al. prepared nanoparticles with a metallic Co9S8 core and S-deficient shell on CNT support (Co9S8− x /CNT) through a hydrothermal process followed by heat treatment in a H2 environment. The treatment at high temperatures facilitated the generation of S deficiencies, which can improve the kinetics of the polysulphide conversion reactions. The prepared Co9S8− x /CNT composite was used as an interlayer on the S cathode to confine the migratory polysulphides and promote their reutilisation [181]. Lu et al. proposed a rational strategy to introduce N vacancies and tune the d-band centre of hexagonal Ni3N. The strong interaction caused by the N vacancies resulted to a high filling fraction of the lowest occupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of Li2S4, thereby weakening and facilitating the breaking of the S–S bond on the Li2S4 backbone (Fig. 19c). From temperature-dependent experiments, the activation energy of nucleation on Ni3N0.85 (8.11 kJ mol−1) was much lower than those on pristine Ni3N (21.11 kJ mol−1) and carbon (33.02 kJ mol−1) [182]. In addition to anion vacancies, cation vacancies in metal compounds can also be introduced to improve the electrochemical properties of Li–S batteries. For example, Fe3C with different Fe vacancy concentrations (Fe3− x C@C) was synthesised by controlling the calcination temperature. The enriched Fe vacancies provided abundant adsorption sites that facilitated the chemical interactions between Fe3− x C@C and LiPSs and catalytic sites that accelerated the kinetics of the LiPS conversion reactions. As shown in Fig. 19(b), the Li2S6 adsorption energy of Fe3− x C was higher than of Fe3C, indicating the higher affinity of LiPS to Fe3− x C. The Fe d-band centre on Fe3− x C was higher than that on Fe3C. This suggests that the Fe vacancies tailored the electronic structure of Fe and therefore, enhanced the adsorption of Li2S6. On the other hand, the decomposition of Li2S on Fe3− x C had a much lower energy barrier than that of the reaction on Fe3C. This further confirms that the Fe vacancies facilitated the kinetics of Li2S transformation [183]. 4.3 Band engineering The unoccupied d orbitals of transition metals are regarded as catalytic active sites. The state of these orbitals was changed with the environment. The distance between the d-band or new hybrid orbits and the Fermi level influences the electronic concentration on the interface, which affects the anchoring and catalytic properties of the catalysts. The energy band engineering can be well understood using the activation barriers, electrode structures, and adsorption energies obtained through theoretical calculations. [184]. The properties of different metal compounds vary greatly, which necessitates the understanding of the role of the p-band of the anions. Qian et al. prepared a series of Co-based compounds such as Co3O4, CoS2, Co4N, and CoP. By using the same metal cation and varying the non-metal anions, the effect of p-band on the Li–S chemistry was systematically investigated [125]. DFT calculations revealed that the variation on the electrochemical performances of these Co-based compounds can be attributed mainly to the shifting of the p-band centres, which modulated the interfacial electron transfer dynamics on the Li-S chemistry. The p-band centre in CoP has a distinct upshift with respect to the Fermi level, thus reducing the energy gap between the Co 3d and anion 2p band centres. The phosphide anion is softer and less electron-pulling than O2− and S2− anions, which increase the energy of the bonding states and reduce the energy gap between the bonding and antibonding orbitals. Higher electron energies are attained due to the higher hybridisation and more contribution of the anions to the valence band electrons. In turn, electron exchange is facilitated to improve the dynamics of the interfacial S6 2−/S2− redox reactions (Fig. 20 a–c). Similarly, Co dopants in Ni2Co4P3 increase the d-band of the metal sites and strengthen the interaction between the metal compounds and LiPSs, which lower the activation barrier. From theoretical analysis, the terminal S atoms were adsorbed onto triply bridged metal sites through strong metal–S bonds. The S–S bonds of the polysulphides were weakened because of the redistribution of the electron population, which facilitated the decomposition of LiPSs into Li2S (Fig. 20d–f) [185]. 4.4 Heterostructure engineering Heterostructures can improve the electron transfer and ion diffusion kinetics due to the induced internal charge transfer driving force in the Li-S batteries [186,187]. They provide interfacial active catalytic sites. More often, synergism is achieved between the desirable properties of the components of the heterostructures [188–193]. To improve the electrical conductivity and increase the active sites of layered double hydroxides (LDHs), Wang et al. fabricated NiCo-LDH/Co9S8 heterostructures with an ordered nanocage morphology through the in-situ transformation of ZIF-67 [194]. The heterostructure exhibited strong interfacial internal electric fields, uniform electron redistributions, and a high conductivity of 663.9 S m−1 (Fig. 21 a). The binding energy of Li2S6 on the LDHs was higher than that on Co9S8 (Fig. 21b). Furthermore, Co9S8 was the preferential site for the conversion of LiPS (Fig. 21c). These results revealed that the anchoring of LiPS and the catalysis of the conversion reaction were simultaneously achieved. At 0.1C, the NiCo-LDH/Co9S8 cathode delivered a high discharge capacity approximately 1340 mAh g−1. Zhao et al. performed the nitridation of CC@Co9S8 using NH3. After the reaction, Co9S8 was transformed to Co4N [195]. By controlling the nitridation time, the obtained p-n Co9S8-Co4N heterostructures limited the LiPS dissolution due to its improved chemical adsorption on the heterostructures. In addition, many active sites and boundary defects at the Co9S8 -Co4N interface were available, which efficiently promoted the conversion of the long-chain LiPS to Li2S2/Li2S (Fig. 21d, e). For 1000 cycles of polarisation at 5C, the free-standing S/CC@Co9S8 -Co4N cathode registered a very low-capacity decay rate of 0.027% per cycle due to its unique structure and superior composition. Similarly, Yang et al. constructed a Fe2O3 -Fe3C heterostructure to anchor LiPS and accelerate its conversion reaction [196]. After 300 cycles at 1C, this cathode delivered a high capacity of 776 mAh g−1. After more than 100 cycles of polarisation at 0.5C, the specific capacities obtained at S loading as high as 3.5 and 4.5 mg cm−2 were 770 and 530 mAh g−1, respectively. Generally, heterostructure engineering and defect engineering can cause the change of energy band. Therefore, a lot of work is focused on the exploration and development of heterostructure engineering and defect engineering. The performance of some representative literatures is shown in the Table S2. Compared to the properties in Table S1, electrochemical properties modified by defect engineering and heterostructure engineering are improved, especially at high current densities. 5 Perspective and conclusions In this review, recent works on the improvement of the electrochemical properties of Li-S batteries with Fe-, Co-, and Ni-based materials are summed up. Firstly, the mechanism and challenge of Li-S are described in brief terms. Afterward, the formation mechanism and properties for chemical binding force between Fe-, Co-, and Ni-based materials and LiPSs are analysed. Furthermore, various catalytic processes, including LiPSs to Li2S1/2, Li2S2 to Li2S, Li2S1/2 to LiPSs, were investigated and evaluated for recent progress. Finally, the four modification methods, including the special micro/nanostructure engineering, defect engineering, band engineering, and phase engineering for the improvement of the electrochemical properties of Fe-, Co-, and Ni-based materials in Li-S batteries are provided. Despite the exciting advances, there is still a lot of space to further explore the anchoring and catalytic abilities to facilitate sulphur transformations. Strenuous efforts should be focused on the following areas. (i) Most of literatures are focused on the conversion for LiPSs to Li2S1/2 to reduce the residence time of polysulfide in the electrolyte and achieve the result of inhabiting shuttle effect. The conversion process for Li2S2 to Li2S that contribute most to capacity are rarely studied. This is because it is difficult to distinguish solid products according to current testing methods [197]. The metal catalysts have been detected to accelerate Li2S2 to Li2S by in suit XANEs characterization [153]. Further development of more advanced and comprehensive testing methods to reveal the mechanism of Li2S2 to Li2S conversion will lead to a better understanding of the principles of Li-S batteries and metal-S systems. (ii) The balance of high sulfur loading and low electrolyte/sulfur ratio is required for commercial application of Li-S batteries. Aiming to this goal, one of the most efficient method is that the catalysts are turned into an intermediate layer [198]. However, this is often neglected to calculate the proportion of the catalyst in the whole cathode materials in most of literatures, which should be paid attention to address. (iii) It should be determined if the metal-based catalysts undergo phase transitions, such as the transformations of Co4N into Co x S y and Ni3FeN into Ni3Fe x N phase, during the electrochemical cycling [126,127]. This requires attention to the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst after the cycle. For example, advanced in situ characterisation techniques can be employed to monitor the changes that occur inside the battery during operation. (iv) Theoretical calculations and machine learning have become powerful tools to guide the design of ideal mediators and the prediction and interpretation of catalytic mechanisms. Non-metal ions affect the conductivity, polarity, and performance of the catalysts. Therefore, understanding the anchoring mechanism, determining the binding strength, and evaluating the catalytic performance of metal compounds with different anions towards LiPSs are beneficial for the design sulphur host materials and reduce the number of trials required to determine the high-performance catalysts by theoretical calculations and machine learning [63,199]. Finally, a clear understanding on the mechanism of the confinement and catalytic conversion of polysulphides on transition metal-based compounds paves a way for the improvement of the utilisation rate of S and inhibition of the shuttle effect. These are beneficial for the design and fabrication of cheap, efficient, and safe Li-S batteries. Furthermore, the theoretical and experimental knowledge on electrocatalysts can be extended to other catalytic fields. Lastly, understanding the catalytic behaviour of Fe-, Co–, and Ni-based compounds and improving their electrochemical and kinetic properties will be beneficial for the industrialisation of high-performance Li-S batteries. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 114 (2017) 840–845. Junhao Li received his B.S. degree from Guangzhou University in 2017 and master degree from Guangdong University of Technology in 2020. He is a doctor candidate in Guangdong University of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Quanbing Liu. The research interests focus on transition metal compounds with the specific structure for lithium secondary batteries. Zhangshi Xiong is currently pursuing a master's student of light industry and chemical engineering of Guangdong University of Technology, under the supervision of Prof. Quanbing Liu. The main research direction is the active catalyst of lithium sulfur battery. Yujie Wu received her B.S. degree from Hubei Engineering University in 2020. Now she is a master candidate in Guangdong University of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Quanbing Liu. Her research interests focus on new energy materials and devices for Li-S chemistry. Xinyan Liu is a professor at Institute of Fundamental and Frontier Sciences (IFFS), University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC). She received her B.S. degree from Tsinghua University in 2013 and Ph.D. degree from Stanford Univerisity in 2018, respectively. After working at Facebook Inc. and Tsinghua University, she joined in IFFS, UESTC at 2022. Prof. Liu’s research interests mainly focus on the interdisciplinary research of energy chemistry, theoretical simulations, and artificial intelligence. Hong-Jie Peng is a professor at Institute of Fundamental and Frontier Sciences (IFFS), University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC). He received his B.S. and Ph.D. degrees from Tsinghua University in 2013 and 2018, respectively. After working as a postdoctoral fellow at SUNCAT center, Stanford University, he joined in IFFS, UESTC at 2021. His research interests focus on advanced energy chemistry and related materials such as lithium–sulfur batteries and catalytic carbon dioxide conversion. He is selected as highly cited researchers in 2019–2021 by Clarivate Analytics. Quanbing Liu is a professor at School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology (GDUT), China. He received her B.S. degree from Wuhan Institute of Technology in 2007 and Ph.D. degree from South China University of Technology in 2012, respectively. After working at CETC-18. and Zhuhai CosMX Battery Co., Ltd, he joined in GDUT at 2016. His research focuses on new energy materials and devices for electrochemical energy storage and conversion, including lithium/lithium-ion/lithium sulfur batteries, electrocatalysis/fuel cell, super capacitor, hydrogen production, and so on.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have a high theoretical capacity, which is considered as one of the most promising high-energy–density secondary batteries due to the double electrons reaction of sulfur. However, the shuttle effects of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and sluggish redox kinetics lead to their materials capacity loss and cycle stability deterioration, which restrains LSBs commercialization. Metallic compounds as additions can improve the electrochemical performance of the Li–S system, through the trap of LiPSs and accelerate the conversion of the soluble LiPSs. Among of them, the iron group elements (Fe, Ni, Co)-based compounds are the promising materials for the LSBs, due to their unique outer electronic structure and its tunable properties, low cost, abundant in the earth, environmental benignity, controllable and scalable prepared, and so on. In this review, we have made a summary for iron-based compounds to capture LiPSs according to lithium bond, sulfur bond and magnetic force. The type of iron-based compound including oxides, sulfides, nitrides, phosphides, carbides, and so on, and we have investigated the electrocatalytic mechanism of these materials. Besides, some improvement strategies are proposed, such as the engineering of the special micro/nanostructure, defect concentrations, band structures, and heterostructures. We hope to shed an in-depth light on the rationally design and fabrication of robust, commercial and stable materials for high-performance LSBs.
